p: The reproductive number (R 0) of the novel infection is estimated by the World Health Organization (WHO) to range between 2 and 2.5, which is higher than that for SARS (1.7–1.9) and MERS (<1), suggesting that SARS-CoV-2 has a higher pandemic potential [ [18], [19], [20], [21], [22]]. However, it must be noted that some published studies have estimated an R 0 for SARS reaching the value of 4 [ 23]. Interestingly, a recent review by Liu and colleagues has shown that the average reproductive number of SARS-CoV-2 is estimated to be 3.28, with a median value of 2.79, thus exceeding the WHO estimates [ 24]. Nonetheless, in Table 1 we report only the WHO data, since the estimation of R 0 depends on the estimation method used, and the current estimate can be biased by insufficient data and the short onset times of the diseases, as Liu and colleagues also state.
